awd_titl_txt: Studies of Viscophoresis -- Drift in a Viscosity Gradient
awd_abstract_narration:
Non-technical Abstract:
By applying a difference in pressure, voltage, or temperature to the ends of a tube filled with liquid, we can cause the fluid or small particles within it to move, and the mechanisms underlying the motion are well understood.  It was recently discovered that when a small glass tube is filled with liquid and the viscosity is held at different values at either end, an electrical current begins to flow; the origin of that motion of electrical charges is not understood at present. This project is experimentally investigating the origins of that phenomenon by measuring the motion of salt ions and small fluorescent particles inside nanofluidic channels, where the physical dimensions and the properties of the liquid can be carefully controlled. The results shed new light onto the theory of the Brownian motion - the random motion of small particles caused by its collisions with the molecules of a liquid. Remarkably, more than a century after the publication of Einstein's famous theory of Brownian motion, the question of whether a particle drifts in a viscosity gradient, and if so, in which direction, is still debated. The conventional picture of the Brownian motion is a walk with steps taken in random directions and step sizes that are inversely proportional to the viscosity.  When the viscosity varies in space, one must choose whether the size of each step in the random walk corresponds to the viscosity at the beginning of the step, the end of the step, or somewhere in between, and this seemingly insignificant choice has measurable consequences.  In fact, different choices can be appropriate in different physical situations. Experiments can settle the debate and deepen our understanding of microscopic phenomena that are important in living cells, in industrial applications, and possibly beyond. The team is producing a scientific cartoon to explain the Brownian motion and its fundamental importance to a broad audience of non-specialists.
 
Technical Abstract:
This project is exploring the origins of a recently discovered nanofluidic transport phenomenon whereby small particles in solution drift due to a gradient in the viscosity of the solvent. The team has named this transport phenomenon "viscophoresis". Measurements of the transport of ions and fluorescent quantum dots in nanofluidic devices with well-defined dimensions establish the quantitative relationships between the drift velocity, the viscosity gradient, and other experimental parameters. The results of those experiments are needed to shed new light on the longstanding "Ito-Stratonovich" theoretical problem of noise-driven dynamics with multiplicative noise. Viscophoresis is significant because nanofluidic transport processes play a vital role in biology, in geology, and in micro- and nanofluidic technology. This project can lead to new insights or applications in those domains, where large viscosity gradients frequently arise. This project provides an excellent training opportunity for a graduate student, and an educational scientific cartoon is being created to reach a broad audience of non-specialists.

por.por_cntn:
One can cause fluid or small particles to move within a liquid-filled tube by applying a difference in pressure, voltage, or temperature across the ends. The physical explanations for those types of motion are well understood.  However, we recently made the surprising discovery that an electrical current can be made to flow by imposing a difference in liquid viscosity between the ends of a small glass tube.  In this project, we studied the motion of different types of particles in a liquid with varying viscosity to provide a comprehensive description and a theoretical explanation for the observed motion.  

We experimentally investigated the origin of that motion by measuring how salt ions and fluorescent particles move within nanofluidic channels.  Salt ions are charged, so their net flow could be inferred by immersing electrodes in the liquid on either side of the channel and measuring the electrical current.  Fluorescent nanoparticles could be individually tracked using an optical microscope, which enabled us to determine the average motion of single particles and the net motion of the collection.  Nanofluidic channels are a convenient arena in which to study this new phenomenon because we could create channels with very precise dimensions using fabrication techniques similar to those used to create electronic circuits on computer chips.  We could also create a viscosity gradient within a nanochannel by flowing a more viscous fluid past one end and a less viscous fluid past the other. Importantly, our nanofluidic experiments enabled us to measure and analyze ionic currents and fluorescent nanoparticle motions in the same nanochannels and under exactly the same experimental conditions.  

We found that the motions of ions and fluorescent nanoparticles are all manifestations of Brownian motion. Einstein famously showed that the Brownian motion of an object is fundamentally linked to its viscous drag in a fluid because the same atomic-scale bumps that cause Brownian motion also randomize the motion of a drifting particle and eventually bring it to rest. It is not possible to know the details of the atomic-scale bumps, but one can model a Brownian motion as a string of small displacements that resembles a random walk. The correct way to add up those displacements is to follow the “isothermal rule”; this requires one to add up random steps whose length depends on the viscosity where the step ends. This rule challenges our intuition because it seems to suggest a particle can see into the future when it begins a random displacement and knows in advance about conditions where it will land.  This rule has other interesting implications for the motion of particles, which we have verified.

We confirmed that particles, be they ions of fluorescent nanoparticles, drift in a viscosity gradient in the direction of decreasing viscosity, moving with an average speed that obeys a simple and fundamental relationship.  But despite the average motion of individual particles, there is no net transfer of nanoparticles from one side of a channel to the other. That counterintuitive finding is in agreement with the isothermal rule: no flux occurs when particles are confined within closed boundaries or are connected to large reservoirs on either end of a channel.  Remarkably, in the same nanochannels, the viscosity gradient caused a measurable current of ions to flow, this net transfer corresponding to positive ions moving along the charged surfaces of the nanochannel in the direction of decreasing viscosity.  This result is also in agreement with the isothermal rule, as long as we account for the ability of ions to adsorb to one electrode and be released from the other.  In other words, we found that different Brownian particles all move in the same manner in a liquid viscosity gradient, but they can be subject to different interactions at the ends that either prohibit any net transfer (as in the case of the fluorescent nanoparticles) or permit a steady flow (as in the case of ions between electrodes).  

Brownian motion is a manifestation of random thermal forces, and while investigating its properties in viscosity gradients, we also investigated the other types of motion driven by random forces: We developed a method of imposing random electrical forces on DNA molecules in nanofluidic channels whose amplitude could be easily varied; this enabled us to study DNA motions under random forces that would otherwise require temperatures exceeding 5000 K to achieve.  We also investigated the motion of DNA and filamentous virus particles subject to the random forces induced in gradients of salt concentration; we observed molecules being driven in the direction of higher salt concentrations by a phenomenon called diffusiophoresis.
